text: You can see a lot, just by looking.
Did you ever see such a thing as a drawing of a muchness?
source: Lewis Carroll, the Dormouse, in Alice in Wonderland

text: The critical requirement of an effective graphical display is that it stimulate spontaneous perceptions of *structure* in data.
Like good writing, producing an effective graphical display requires an understanding of *purpose*---*what* is to be communicated, and to *whom*.
Have you ever seen voice mail?
Graphics is the visual means of resolving logical problems.
The greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we never expected to see.

If one technique of data analysis were to be exalted above all others for its ability to be revealing to the mind in connection with each of many different models, there is little doubt which one would be chosen. The simple graph has brought more information to the data analyst's mind than any other device. It specializes in providing indications of unexpected phenomena.
Genius seems to consist merely in trueness of sight.
The eye obeys exactly the action of the mind.
Vision is the art of seeing things invisible.
When there is no vision, the people perish.
If I can't picture it, I can't understand it.
And those who have insight will shine brightly like the brightness of the expanse of Heaven.

The one thing that marks the true artist is a clear perception and a firm, bold hand, in distinction from that imperfect mental vision and uncertain truth which give up the feeble pictures and the lumpy statues of the mere artisans on canvas or in stone.
source: Oliver Wendell Holmes (1860), The Professor at the Breakfast Table Ticknor and Fields, Boston, MA

text: I like your motto: One picture is worth 1,000 denials.
source: Ronald Reagan to White House News Photographers Assn, 18 May 1983

text: With brush you paint the possibilities; with pens you scribe the probabilities; for in pictures we find insight; while in numbers find we strength.
A graphic should not only show the leaves; it should show the branches as well as the entire tree.

Tables are like cobwebs, like the sieve of Danaides; beautifully reticulated, orderly to look upon, but which will hold no conclusion. Tables are abstractions, and the object a most concrete one, so difficult to read the essence of.
source: From Chartism by Thomas Carlyle (1840), Chapter II, Statistics

text: A judicious man looks at Statistics, not to get knowledge, but to save himself from having ignorance foisted on him.
source: Thomas Carlyle, Chartism Chapter II, Statistics

text: Although geometrical representations of propositions in the thermodynamics of fluids are in general use and have done good service in disseminating clear notions in this science, yet they have by no means received the extension in respect to variety and generality of which they are capable.
source: J. Willard Gibbs, Graphical Methods in the Thermodynamics of Fluids}, 1873 \citeyear{Gibbs:1873a

text: Although we often hear that data speak for themselves, their voices can be soft and sly.
source: Mosteller, Fienberg and Rourke, Beginning Statistics with Data Analysis 1983, Reading MA, p. 234

text: Nocturne, of Chopin, so beautiful music. But few people will appreciate the music if I just show them the notes. Most of us need to listen to the music to understand how beautiful it is. But often that's how we present statistics; we just show the notes, we don't play the music.
source: Hans Rosling, OECD World Forum, Istanbul, June 2007

text: The greatest possibilities of visual display lie in vividness and inescapability of the intended message. A visual display can stop your mental flow in its tracks and make you think. A visual display can force you to notice what you never expected to see.
The purpose of [data] display is comparison (recognition of phenomena), not numbers ... The phenomena are the main actors, numbers are the supporting cast.
If an editor should print bad English he would lose his position. Many editors are using and printing bad methods of graphic presentation, but they hold their jobs just the same.
source: W. C. Brinton, Graphic methods of presenting facts 1914, p. 3

text: Around the turn of the century, Karl Pearson, an almost elemental force for more and better statistical thought in all areas of life, including with gusto, matters of social policy, was thinking and lecturing about graphical methods. But later in Pearson's life, and certainly in the careers of R. A. Fisher and the other great statistical minds of the first half of the century, there was a falling away of interest in graphics and an efflorescence  of devotion to analytical mathematical methods. Indeed, for many years there was a contagious *snobbery* against so unpopular, vulgar and elementary a topic as graphics among academic statisticians and their students

If statistical graphics, although born just yesterday, extends its reach every day, it is because it replaces long tables of numbers and it allows one not only to embrace at glance the series of phenomena, but also to signal the correspondences or anomalies, to find the causes, to identify the laws.
Numbers have an important story to tell. They rely on you to give them a clear and convincing voice
Visualizations act as a campfire around which we gather to tell stories
The purpose of visualization is insight, not pictures
I love taxonomies, categories, ways of dividing people into groups
Ballerinas are often divided into three categories: jumpers, turners and balancers

Mr. Funkhouser has made an extremely interesting and valuable contribution to the history of statistical method. I wish, however, that he could have added a warning, supported by horrid examples, of the evils of the graphical method unsupported by tables of  figures. Both for  accurate understanding, and particularly to facilitate the use of the same material by other people, it is essential that graphs should not be published by themselves, but only when supported by the tables which lead up to them. It would be an exceedingly good rule to forbid in any scientific periodical the publication of graphs unsupported by tables.
source: John Maynard Keynes, review of Funkhouser for The Economic Journal http://www.jstor.org/stable/2224943

text: Without data you are just another person with an opinion
Without a plot you are just a person missing a convincing argument

Whatever relates to extent and quantity may be represented by geometrical figures. Statistical projections which speak to the senses without fatiguing the mind, possess the advantage of fixing the attention on a great number of important facts.
Segnius irritant animos demissa per aures, Quam quae sunt oculus subjecta fidelibus (Roughly: What we hear excites the mind less than what we see)
You see, but you do not observe. The distinction is clear.
source: Sherlock Holmes, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes (1890), "A Scandal in Bohemia", p. 162

text: Every picture tells a story.
A picture is worth a ten thousand words.
source: Fred R. Barnard, March 10 1927 in the advertising trade journal Printers Ink

text: ...But it is not always clear *which* 1000 words.
Un croquis vaut mieux qu'un long discours. Tr.: A good sketch is better than a long speech.
A picture is worth a thousand numbers.
Show me your flowcharts and conceal your tables, and I shall continue to be mystified. Show me your tables, and I won't usually need your flowcharts; they'll be obvious.
Look here, upon this picture, and on this.
I am only a picture-taster, the way others are wine- or tea-tasters.
source: Bernard Berenson, Sunset and Twilight Harcourt, Brace & World, 1963

text: Getting information from a table is like extracting sunlight from a cucumber.

When a law is contained in figures, it is buried like metal in an ore; it is necessary to extract it.  This is the work of graphical representation. It points out the coincidences, the relationships between phenomena, their anomalies, and we have seen what a powerful means of control it puts in the hands of the statistician to verify new data, discover and correct errors with which they have been stained.
source: Emile Cheysson, Les m\ethods de la statistique (1890), 34-35.

text: [When] you see excellent graphics, find out how they were done. Borrow strength from demonstrated excellence.  The idea for information design is: Don't get it original, get it right.
Good design is obvious. Great design is transparent.
source: Joe Sparano, graphic designer for Oxide Design Co.

text: Content precedes design. Design in the absence of content is not design, it's decoration.
source: Jeffrey Zeldman, web designer and entrepreneur

text: Mankind is not a circle with a single center but an ellipse with two focal points of which facts are one and ideas the other.
So, Fabricius, I already have this: that the most true path of the planet [Mars] is an ellipse, which Durer also calls an oval, or certainly so close to an ellipse that the difference is insensible
Programming graphics in X is like finding the square root of $\pi$ using Roman numerals.
The purpose of computing is insight, not numbers.
source: Richard Hamming, Introduction To Applied Numerical Analysis

text: ... to be a good theoretical statistician one must also compute, and must therefore have the best computing aids.
source: Frank Yates, Sampling Methods for Censuses and Surveys 1949

text: We [he and Halmos] share a philosophy about linear algebra: we think basis-free, we write basis-free, but when the chips are down we close the office door and compute with matrices like fury.
source: Kaplansky, Irving Paul Halmos: Celebrating 50 Years of Mathematics

text: Seek computer programs that allow you to do the thinking.
If you only know how to use a hammer, every problem starts to look like a nail.  Stay away from that trap.
[It is] best to confuse only one issue at a time.
The nice thing about standards is that there are so many of them to choose from.
There are no routine statistical questions, only questionable statistical routines.
Be careful the environment you choose for it will shape you; be careful the friends you choose for you will become like them.
Be careless in your dress if you must, but keep a tidy soul
I'm a tidy sort of bloke. I don't like chaos. I kept records in the record rack, tea in the tea caddy, and pot in the pot box
Thou shalt not sit with statisticians nor commit a Social Science.
There are two kinds of statistics, the kind you look up and the kind you make up.
Statistics are like alienists -- they will testify for either side.
You may prove anything by figures.
To understand God's thoughts we must study statistics, for these are the measure of His purpose.
You cannot feed the hungry on statistics.
A single death is a tragedy, a million deaths is a statistic.
source: Kurt Tucholsky, in: Franzosischer Witz, 1925, mis-attributed to Joseph Stalin

text: A judicious man uses statistics, not to get knowledge, but to save himself from having ignorance foisted upon him.
Statistics are like a bikini.  What they reveal is suggestive, but what they conceal is vital.
Do not put faith in what statistics say until you have carefully considered what they do not say.
Facts are stubborn things, but statistics are more pliable.
Statistics are figures used as arguments.
Figures won't lie but liars will figure.

I always find that statistics are hard to swallow and impossible to digest.  The only one I can remember is that if all the people who go to sleep in church were laid end to end they would be a lot more comfortable.
Statistician: Delphic figure who lacks the necessary vocabulary to converse with mere mortals.
Get the facts first, and then you can distort them as much as you please.
If you want to inspire confidence, give plenty of statistics. It does not matter that they should be accurate, or even intelligible, as long as there is enough of them.
It is a truth very certain that when it is not in our power to determine what is true we ought to follow what is most probable.
Models are to be used, but not to be believed.
A beautiful theory, killed by a nasty, ugly little fact.
The deepest sin of the human mind is to believe things without evidence.
Man must learn to simplify, but not to the point of falsification.
Do not put your faith in what statistics say until you have carefully considered what they do not say.
Since small differences in probability cannot be appreciated by the human mind, there seems little point in being excessively precise about uncertainty.
source: Box, G. E. P. & Tiao, G. C. (1973), Bayesian inference in statistical analysis Addison-Wesley, Reading, MA, p. 65.

text: Some people hate the very name of statistics but I find them full of beauty and interest.  Whenever they are not brutalized, but delicately handled by the higher methods, and are warily interpreted,  their power of dealing with complicated phenomena is extraordinary.
[Statistics are] the only tools by which an opening may be cut through the formidable thicket of difficulties that bars the path of those who pursue the Science of Man.
source: Galton, quoted in K. Pearson, The Life, Letters and Labours of Francis Galton (London, 1914)

text: Data analysis is an aid to thinking and not a replacement for.
Sometimes the only thing you can do with a poorly designed experiment is to try to find out what it died of.
The best time to plan an experiment is after you've done it.
[The War Office kept three sets of figures:] one to mislead the public, another to mislead the Cabinet, and the third to mislead itself.
source: Herbert Asquith in Alistair Horne, Price of Glory

text: Why are you testing your data for normality?  For large sample sizes the normality tests often give a meaningful answer to a meaningless question (for small samples they give a meaningless answer to a meaningful question)

The relevant question is not whether ANOVA assumptions are met exactly, but rather whether the plausible violations of the assumptions have serious consequences on the validity of probability statements based on the standard assumptions
Exploratory data analysis can never be the whole story, but nothing else	can serve as the foundation stone -- as the first step.
The best thing about being a statistician is that you get to play in everyone's backyard.
Far better an approximate answer to the right question, which is often vague, than an exact answer to the wrong question, which can always be made precise.
source: John W. Tukey, (1962), "The future of data analysis," Annals of Mathematical Statistics 33, 1-67.

text: A bad answer to a good question may be far better than a good answer to a bad question.
source: A graduate class, paraphrasing Tukeys dictum.

text: The worst, i.e., most dangerous, feature of 'accepting the null hypothesis' is the giving up of explicit uncertainty ... Mathematics can sometimes be put in such black-and-white terms, but our knowledge or belief about the external world never can.
source: John W. Tukey. (1991). "The Philosophy of Multiple Comparisons," Statistical Science 6, 100--116.

text: Better to have an approximate answer to the right question than a precise answer to the wrong question.
source: John W. Tukey as quoted by John Chambers

text: All models are wrong but some are useful.
Every model is an approximation.
The business of the statistician is to catalyze the scientific learning process.
Statisticians, like artists, have the bad habit of falling in love with their models.
If there were a probability of only p = 0.04 of finding a crock of gold behind the next tree, wouldn't you go and look?
Seek computer programs that allow you to do the thinking.
When the ratio of the largest to smallest observation is large you should question whether the data are being analyzed in the right metric (transformation).
A useful type of time series model is a recipe for transforming serial data into white noise.
It is the data that are real (they actually happened!) The model is a hypothetical conjecture that might or might not summarize and/or explain important features of the data
It is not unusual for a well-designed experiment to analyze itself.
Discovering the unexpected is more important than confirming the known.
We are drowning in information and starving for knowledge.
`Data! data!' he cried impatiently.  I can't make bricks without clay.
source: Arthur Conan-Doyle, Adventures of Sherlock Holmes "The Copper Beeches"

text: I have no data yet. It is a capital mistake to theorize before one has data.
source: Arthur Conan-Doyle, Adventures of Sherlock Holmes "A Scandal in Bohemia"

text: This was an unexpected piece of luck. My data were coming more quickly than I could have reasonably hoped.
source: Arthur Conan-Doyle, Memoirs of Sherlock Holmes, The Musgrave Ritual

text: I have not all my facts yet, but I do not think there are any insuperable difficulties. Still, it is an error to argue in front of your data. You find yourself insensibly twisting them round to fit your theories.
source: Arthur Conan-Doyle, His Last Bow, Wisteria Lodge

text: It is a capital mistake to theorize before one has data.
source: Sherlock Homes in Scandal in Bohemia

text: The only thing we know for sure about a missing data point is that it is not there, and there is nothing that the magic of statistics can do do change that.  The best that can be managed is to estimate the extent to which missing data have influenced the inferences we wish to draw.
Big data can change the way social science is performed, but will not replace statistical common sense.
source: Thomas Landsall-Welfare, "Nowcasting the mood of the nation," Significance v. 9(4), August 12, 2012, p. 28

text: Baseball is ninety percent mental and the other half is physical.
Whenever I see an outlier, I never know whether to throw it away or patent it.
source: Bert Gunter quoting a colleague, R-Help, 9/14/2015

text: In God we trust. All others must bring data.
The combination of some data and an aching desire for an answer does not ensure that a reasonable answer can be extracted from a given body of data.
The plural of anecdote is not data.
How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.
source: Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Sonnets from the Portuguese

text: Not everything that counts can be counted, and not everything that can be counted counts.
Whenever you can, count.

It is difficult to understand why statisticians commonly limit their inquiries to Averages, and do not revel in more comprehensive views. Their souls seem as dull to the charm of variety as that of the native of our flat English counties, whose retrospect of Switzerland was that, if its mountains could be thrown into its lakes, two nuisances would be got rid of at once.

Winwood Reade is good upon the subject. He remarks that, while the individual man is an insoluble puzzle, in the aggregate he becomes a mathematical certainty. You can, for example, never foretell what any one man will do, but you can say with precision what an average number will be up to. Individuals vary, but percentages remain constant. So says the statistician.
source: Arthur Conan-Doyle, Sign of the Four

text: If you put a buttock on a hot plate and another one on an ice cube, the average is good, but in reality your bottom is in trouble.

The graphical method has considerable superiority for the exposition of statistical facts over the tabular. A heavy bank of figures is grievously wearisome to the eye, and the popular mind is as incapable of drawing any useful lessons from it as of extracting sunbeams from cucumbers.
source: Arthur B. & Henry Farquhar (1891). Economic and Industrial Delusions

text: Let it serve for table-talk.
source: William Shakespeare. The Merchant of Venice, Act III, Sc. 5.

text: I drink to the general joy o' the whole table.
source: William Shakespeare. Macbeth, Act III, Sc. 4.

text: Isolated facts, those that can only be obtained by rough estimate and that require development, can only be presented in memoires; but those that can be presented in a body, with details, and on whose accuracy one can rely, may be expounded in tables.
source: E. Duvillard, M{e}moire sur le travail du Bureau de statistique 1806; cited in

text: Study without reflection is a waste of time; reflection without study is dangerous
All truths are easy to understand once they are discovered; the point is to discover them
Things should be made as simple as possible, but not any simpler
So much has already been written about everything that you can't find out anything about it.
The practical power of a statistical test is the product of its' statistical power and the probability of use.
Theory into Practice.
source: Mao Tse-Tung, The Little Red Book

text: ``Beauty is truth; truth, beauty.'' That is all ye know on Earth, and all ye need to know.
source: John Keats, Ode on a Grecian urn

text: They consider me to have sharp and penetrating vision because I see them through the mesh of a sieve.
The journalistic vision sharpens to the point of maximum impact every event, every individual and social configuration; but the honing is uniform.
Some people weave burlap into the fabric of our lives, and some weave gold thread. Both contribute to make the whole picture beautiful and unique.
Time extracts various values from a painter's work. When these values are exhausted the pictures are forgotten, and the more a picture has to give, the greater it is.
God is in the details.
source: Mies van der Rohe, New York Times August 19, 1969

text: The devil is in the details.
One has to be able to count if only so that at fifty one doesn't marry a girl of twenty.
A man has one hundred dollars and you leave him with two dollars, that's subtraction.
In the fields of observation chance favors only the prepared mind.
The eye of a human being is a microscope, which makes the world seem bigger than it really is.
source: Kahlil Gibran, A Handful of Sand on the Shore

text: To the man who only has a hammer in the toolkit, every problem looks like a nail.
Four hostile newspapers are more to be feared than a thousand bayonets.
When I'm working on a problem, I never think about beauty. I think only how to solve the problem. But when I have finished, if the solution is not beautiful, I know it is wrong.
He who asks a question is a fool for five minutes; he who does not ask a question remains a fool forever.
The great tragedy of science -- the slaying of a beautiful hypothesis by an ugly fact.
Give a man to fish and he will eat for a day. Teach a man to fish and he will eat for the rest of his life.
Give a man a fish and he will eat for a day. Teach a man to fish and you lose a consulting job forever.
When you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.
source: Arthur Conan Doyle, The Sign of the Four (1890), Ch. 6

text: If you choose to represent the various parts in life by holes upon a table, of different shapes---some circular, some triangular, some square, some oblong---we shall generally find that the triangular person has got into the square hole, the oblong into the triangular, and a square person has squeezed himself into the round hole.

I know of scarcely anything so apt to impress the imagination as the wonderful form of cosmic order expressed by the ``Law of Frequency of Error.'' The law would have been personified by the Greeks and deified, if they had known of it. It reigns with serenity and in complete self-effacement, amidst the wildest confusion. The huger the mob, and the greater the apparent anarchy, the more perfect is its sway. It is the supreme law of Unreason. Whenever a large sample of chaotic elements are taken in hand and marshaled in the order of their magnitude, an unsuspected and most beautiful form of regularity proves to have been latent all along.
source: Sir Francis Galton, Natural Inheritance London: Macmillan, 1889. Quoted in J. R. Newman (ed.) The World of Mathematics, New York: Simon and Schuster, 1956. p. 1482.

text: In scientific thought we adopt the simplest theory which will explain all the facts under consideration and enable us to predict new facts of the same kind. The catch in this criterion lies in the world ``simplest.'' It is really an aesthetic canon such as we find implicit in our criticisms of poetry or painting. The layman finds such a law as $dx/dt = K(d^2x/dy^2)$ much less simple than "it oozes," of which it is the mathematical statement. The physicist reverses this judgment, and his statement is certainly the more fruitful of the two, so far as prediction is concerned. It is, however, a statement about something very unfamiliar to the plainman, namely, the rate of change of a rate of change.
source: John Burdon Sanderson Haldane (1892--1964) Possible Worlds, 1927.

text: Oh, what a tangled web we weave, When first we practice to deceive!
Practice is the best of all instructors.

We should go to the masses and learn from them, synthesize their experience into better, articulated principles and methods, then do propaganda among the masses, and call upon them to put these principles and methods into practice so as to solve their problems and help them achieve liberation and happiness.
source: Chairman Mao Zedong, "Get Organized!" (November 29, 1943), Selected Works, Vol. III, p. 158.

text: The best thing about being a statistician is that you get to play in everyone's backyard.
An elementary demonstration is one that requires no knowledge--- just an infinite amount of intelligence.
Science may be described as the art of systematic over-simplification.
Science is like sex: sometimes something useful comes out, but that is not the reason we are doing it.

Humanists believe that the world has a fixed number of mysteries, so that when one is solved, our sense of wonder is diminished.  Scientists believe that the world has endless mysteries, so that when one is solved, there are always new ones to ponder.
source: D. O. Hebb, quoted by Steven Pinker

text: Art and science encounter each other when they seek exactitude.
As a rule, the more bizarre a thing is the less mysterious it proves to be.
source: Sherlock Holmes, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes (1892) "The Red-Headed League"

text: Circumstantial evidence is a very tricky thing. It may seem to point very straight to one thing, but if you shift your own point of view a little, you may find it pointing in an equally uncompromising manner to something entirely different.
source: Sherlock Holmes, The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes (1892) "The Boscombe Valley Mystery"

text: To find out what happens when you change something, it is necessary to change it.
source: Box, Hunter, and Hunter, Statistics for Experimenters (1978)

text: With four parameters I can fit an elephant, and with five I can make him wiggle his trunk.
He who loves practice without theory is like the sailor who boards ship without a rudder and compass and never knows where he may be cast.
Science is built up of facts, as a house is with stones. But a collection of facts is no more a science than a heap of stones is a house.
The museum spreads its surfaces everywhere, and becomes an untitled collection of generalizations that mobilize the eye.
In one word, to draw the rule from experience, one must generalize; this is a necessity that imposes itself on the most circumspect observer.
source: Henri Poincare, The Value of Science: Essential Writings of Henri Poincare

text: If I have seen further, it is by standing on the shoulders of giants.
source: Sir Isaac Newton, in a letter to Robert Hooke, Feb. 5, 1676

text: Few intellectual pleasures are more keen than those enjoyed by a person who, while he is occupied in some special inquiry, suddenly perceives that it admits of a wide generalization, and that his results hold good in previously-unsuspected directions.
The elegance of a theorem is directly proportional to the number of ideas you can see in it and inversely proportional to the effort it takes to see them.

A mathematician, like a painter or a poet, is a master of pattern. The mathematician's patterns, like the painter's or the poet's, must be beautiful; the ideas, like the colors or the words, must fit together in a harmonious way. ... There is no permanent place in the world for ugly mathematics.
An idea which can be used once is a trick. If it can be used more than once it becomes a method.
When the time is ripe for certain things, these things appear in different places in the manner of violets coming to light in early spring.
source: Farkas Bolyai to his son Janos Bolyai, urging him to claim the invention of non-Euclidean geometry without delay, quoted in Ming Li and Paul Vitanyi, An introduction to Kolmogorov Complexity and Its Applications, 1st ed., 1993, p. 83.

text: The only new thing in the world is the history you don't know.
source: Harry S. Truman, quoted by David McCulloch

text: So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.
source: F. Scott Fitzgerald, The Great Gatsby (1925)

text: Euclid alone has looked on beauty bare.
The past only exists insofar as it is present in the records of today. And what those records are is determined by what questions we ask.  There is no other history than that.
A generation which ignores history has no past and no future
History will be kind to me for I intend to write it.
For my part, I consider that it will be found much better by all parties to leave the past to history, especially as I propose to write that history myself.
If you would understand anything, observe its beginning and its development.
God alone knows the future, but only an historian can alter the past.
Since God himself cannot change the past, he is obliged to tolerate the existence of historians.
At the heart of good history is a naughty little secret: good storytelling.
It has been said that though God cannot alter the past, historians can; it is perhaps because they can be useful to Him in this respect that He tolerates their existence.
History is moving statistics and statistics is frozen history.
source: A. L. Schlozer, Theorie der Statistik 1804, p. 86

text: Time flies like an arrow; fruit flies like a banana.
source: Anthony G. Oettinger; often mis-attributed to Groucho Marx

text: How did it get so late so soon?
Time is the longest distance between two places.
Those who make the worst use of their time are the first to complain of its brevity.
source: Jean de La Bruy\`ere, Les Caract\`eres

text: The past is a foreign country: they do things differently there.
I never think of the future - it comes soon enough.
The best way to predict the future is to invent it
Prediction is very difficult, especially about the future
The future ain't what it used to be
Look not mournfully into the past. It comes not back again.  Wisely improve the present. It is thine. Go forth to meet the shadowy future, without fear.
Let him who would enjoy a good future waste none of his present.
When in doubt, predict that the present trend will continue.
The only use of a knowledge of the past is to equip us for the present. The present contains all that there is. It is holy ground; for it is the past, and it is the future.
My past is my wisdom to use today. ... my future is my wisdom yet to experience. Be in the present because that is where life resides.
source: Gene Oliver, Life and the Artistry of Change

text: I have realized that the past and future are real illusions, that they exist in the present, which is what there is and all there is.
The future is uncertain but the end is always near.

Time has no divisions to mark its passage, there is never a thunder-storm of blare of trumpets to announce the beginning of a new month or year. Even when a new century begins, it is only we mortals who ring bells and fire off pistols.
Direction is more important than speed. We are so busy looking at our speedometers that we forget the milestone.
Only sixteen players have hit fifty or more homers in a season. To me, that's a very special milestone.
As life runs on, the road grows strange with faces new -- and near the end. The milestones into headstones change, Neath every one a friend.
This paper contains much that is new and much that is true. Unfortunately, that which is true is not new and that which is new is not true.
This book fills a much-needed gap.
Russell left the vast darkness of the topic unobscured
source: Alfred North Whitehead, referring to Bertrand Russell

text: Mathematicians have always been rather of a jealous nature, and undoubtedly jealousy was a family characteristic of the Bernoullis.  There is some excuse for mathematicians, for their reputation stands for posterity largely not on what they did, but on what their contemporaries attributed to them.
source: Karl Pearson, "The History of Statistics in the 17th and 18th Centuries"

text: When choosing between two evils, I always like to take the one I've never tried before.
To err is human---but it feels divine!
Good judgment comes from experience; experience comes from bad judgment.
One must learn by doing the thing; for though you think you know it, you have no certainty until you try.
From carefully compiled statistical facts more may be learned [about] the moral nature of Man than can be gathered from all the accumulated experiences of the preceding ages.
source: Henry Thomas Buckle, A History of Civilization in England, 1857/1898, p. 17

text: Statistical thinking will one day be as necessary for efficient citizenship as the ability to read and write.

Statistical accounts are to be referred to as a dictionary by men of riper years, and by young men as a grammar, to teach them the relations and proportions of different statistical subjects, and to imprint them on the mind at a time when the memory is capable of being impressed in a lasting and durable manner, thereby laying the foundation for accurate and valuable knowledge.
Geography is only a branch of statistics, a knowledge of which is necessary to the well-understanding of the history of nations, as well as their situations relative to each other.
source: William Playfair, The Commercial and Political Atlas, p. 29

text: No study is less alluring or more dry and tedious than statistics, unless the mind and imagination are set to work, or that the person studying is particularly interested in the subject; which last can seldom be the case with young men in any rank of life.
source: William Playfair, The Statistical Breviary (1801), p. 16

text: DIAGRAMS are of great utility for illustrating certain questions of vital statistics by conveying ideas on the subject through the eye, which cannot be so readily grasped when contained in figures.
source: Florence Nightingale, Mortality of the British Army, 1857

text: To give insight to statistical information it occurred to me, that making an appeal to the eye when proportion and magnitude are concerned, is the best and readiest method of conveying a distinct idea.
source: William Playfair, The Statistical Breviary (1801), p. 2

text: Regarding numbers and proportions, the best way to catch the imagination is to speak to the eyes.
source: William Playfair, Elemens de statistique, Paris, 1802, p. XX.

text: The aim of my carte figurative is to convey promptly to the eye the relation not given quickly by numbers requiring mental calculation.

Information that is imperfectly acquired, is generally as imperfectly retained; and a man who has carefully investigated a printed table, finds, when done, that he has only a very faint and partial idea of what he has read; and that like a figure imprinted on sand, is soon totally erased and defaced.
source: William Playfair, The Commercial and Political Atlas (p. 3), 1786

text: Since the aim of exploratory data analysis is to learn what seems to be, it should be no surprise that pictures play a vital role in doing it well.
There is nothing better than a picture for making you think of questions you had forgotten to ask (even mentally).

Functional visualizations are more than innovative statistical analyses and computational algorithms. They must make sense to the user and require a visual language system that uses colour, shape, line, hierarchy and composition to communicate clearly and appropriately, much like the alphabetic and character-based languages used worldwide between humans.
A people without the knowledge of their past history, origin and culture is like a tree without roots

The bushels of rings taken from the fingers of the slain at the battle of Cannae, above two thousand years ago, are recorded; ... but the bushels of corn produced in England at this day, or the number of the inhabitants of the country, are unknown, at the very time that we are debating that most important question, whether or not there is sufficient substance for those who live in the kingdom.
source: William Playfair, The Statistical Breviary (1801), p. 7-8

text: How can the past and future be, when the past no longer is, and the future is not yet? As for the present, if it were always present and never moved on to become the past, it would not be time, but eternity.

Every measurable thing, except numbers, is imagined in the manner of continuous quantity. Therefore, for the mensuration of such a thing, it is necessary that points, lines and surfaces, or their properties be imagined. For in them, as the Philosopher has it, measure or ratio is initially found, while in other things it is recognized by similarity as they are being referred to by the intellect to the geometrical entities.
source: Nicole Oresme, The Latitude of Forms

text: Any one who considers arithmetical methods of producing random digits is, of course, in a state of sin.
With four parameters I can fit an elephant, and with five I can make him wiggle his trunk.
source: John von Neumann, quoted by Freeman Dyson

text: The punishment of every disordered mind is its own disorder.
